drug.name: Carteolol
drug.description: A beta-adrenergic antagonist used as an anti-arrhythmia agent, an anti-angina agent, an antihypertensive agent, and an antiglaucoma agent.

article.citation: El-Kamel A, Al-Dosari H, Al-Jenoobi F: Environmentally responsive ophthalmic gel formulation of carteolol hydrochloride. Drug Deliv. 2006 Jan-Feb;13(1):55-9.
Kuwahara K, Oizumi N, Fujisawa S, Tanito M, Ohira A: Carteolol hydrochloride protects human corneal epithelial cells from UVB-induced damage in vitro. Cornea. 2005 Mar;24(2):213-20.
Trinquand C, Romanet JP, Nordmann JP, Allaire C: [Efficacy and safety of long-acting carteolol 1% once daily. A double-masked, randomized study]. J Fr Ophtalmol. 2003 Feb;26(2):131-6.

drug.synthesis-reference: Tamura,Y., Nakagawa,K., Yoshizaki,S.and Murakami,N.; U.S.Patent 3,910,924; October 7, 1975; assigned to Otsuka Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd.
drug.indication: For the treatment of intraocular hypertension and chronic open-angle glaucoma
drug.pharmacodynamics: Carteolol is a beta1 and beta2 (non-selective) adrenergic receptor-blocking agent that does not have significant intrinsic sympathomimetic, direct myocardial depressant, or local anesthetic (membrane-stabilizing) activity. Carteolol, when applied topically to the eye, has the action of reducing elevated, as well as normal, intraocular pressure, whether or not accompanied by glaucoma. Elevated intraocular pressure is a major risk factor in the pathogenesis of glaucomatous visual field loss and optic nerve damage. Carteolol reduces intraocular pressure with little or no effect on pupil size or accommodation in contrast to the miosis which cholinergic agents are known to produce.
drug.mechanism-of-action: The primary mechanism of the ocular hypotensive action of carteolol in reducing intraocular pressure is most likely a decrease in aqueous humor production. This process is initiated by the non-selective beta1 and beta2 adrenergic receptor blockade.
drug.toxicity: The most common effects expected with overdosage of a beta-adrenergic blocking agent are bradycardia, bronchospasm, congestive heart failure and hypotension.

classification.description: This compound belongs to the class of organic compounds known as hydroquinolines. These are derivatives of quinoline in which in which at least one double bond in the quinoline moiety are reduced by adding two hydrogen atoms.

packager.name: Pharmaceutical Utilization Management Program VA Inc.

drug-interaction.name: Trazodone
drug-interaction.description: The risk or severity of QTc prolongation can be increased when Trazodone is combined with Carteolol.

drug-interaction.name: Pitolisant
drug-interaction.description: Carteolol may increase the QTc-prolonging activities of Pitolisant.

drug-interaction.name: Lefamulin
drug-interaction.description: Lefamulin may increase the QTc-prolonging activities of Carteolol.

drug-interaction.name: Methimazole
drug-interaction.description: The excretion of Carteolol can be decreased when combined with Methimazole.

drug-interaction.description: Quetiapine may increase the hypotensive activities of Carteolol.

drug-interaction.description: Lasmiditan may increase the bradycardic activities of Carteolol.

drug-interaction.name: Verapamil
drug-interaction.description: The risk or severity of adverse effects can be increased when Verapamil is combined with Carteolol.

drug-interaction.name: Escitalopram
drug-interaction.description: The serum concentration of Carteolol can be increased when it is combined with Escitalopram.

drug-interaction.name: Dronedarone
drug-interaction.description: The metabolism of Carteolol can be decreased when combined with Dronedarone.

drug-interaction.name: Givosiran
drug-interaction.description: The serum concentration of Carteolol can be increased when it is combined with Givosiran.

article.citation: Wheeldon NM, McDevitt DG, Lipworth BJ: Evaluation of in vivo partial beta 1/beta 2-agonist activity: a dose-ranging study with carteolol. Br J Clin Pharmacol. 1992 Apr;33(4):411-6.

Bruck H, Poller U, Lussenhop H, Ponicke K, Temme T, Heusch G, Philipp T, Brodde OE: Beta 2-adrenoceptor-mediated intrinsic sympathomimetic activity of carteolol: an in vivo study. Naunyn Schmiedebergs Arch Pharmacol. 2004 Nov;370(5):361-8. Epub 2004 Oct 23.
Chen X, Ji ZL, Chen YZ: TTD: Therapeutic Target Database. Nucleic Acids Res. 2002 Jan 1;30(1):412-5.

polypeptide.name: Beta-2 adrenergic receptor
polypeptide.specific-function: Beta-adrenergic receptors mediate the catecholamine-induced activation of adenylate cyclase through the action of G proteins. The beta-2-adrenergic receptor binds epinephrine with an approximately 30-fold greater affinity than it does norepinephrine.

go-classifier.description: activation of transmembrane receptor protein tyrosine kinase activity
adenylate cyclase-activating adrenergic receptor signaling pathway
adenylate cyclase-modulating G-protein coupled receptor signaling pathway
desensitization of G-protein coupled receptor protein signaling pathway by arrestin
mitophagy in response to mitochondrial depolarization
negative regulation of multicellular organism growth
negative regulation of smooth muscle contraction
positive regulation of potassium ion transport
positive regulation of skeletal muscle tissue growth
positive regulation of sodium ion transport
positive regulation of the force of heart contraction by epinephrine
positive regulation of transcription from RNA polymerase II promoter
regulation of sensory perception of pain
vasodilation by norepinephrine-epinephrine involved in regulation of systemic arterial blood pressure

article.citation: Chen X, Ji ZL, Chen YZ: TTD: Therapeutic Target Database. Nucleic Acids Res. 2002 Jan 1;30(1):412-5.

Bruck H, Poller U, Lussenhop H, Ponicke K, Temme T, Heusch G, Philipp T, Brodde OE: Beta 2-adrenoceptor-mediated intrinsic sympathomimetic activity of carteolol: an in vivo study. Naunyn Schmiedebergs Arch Pharmacol. 2004 Nov;370(5):361-8. Epub 2004 Oct 23.

Chidlow G, Melena J, Osborne NN: Betaxolol, a beta(1)-adrenoceptor antagonist, reduces Na(+) influx into cortical synaptosomes by direct interaction with Na(+) channels: comparison with other beta-adrenoceptor antagonists. Br J Pharmacol. 2000 Jun;130(4):759-66.

Floreani M, Froldi G, Quintieri L, Varani K, Borea PA, Dorigo MT, Dorigo P: In vitro evidence that carteolol is a nonconventional partial agonist of guinea pig cardiac beta1-adrenoceptors: a comparison with xamoterol. J Pharmacol Exp Ther. 2005 Dec;315(3):1386-95. Epub 2005 Sep 13.

polypeptide.name: Beta-1 adrenergic receptor
polypeptide.specific-function: Beta-adrenergic receptors mediate the catecholamine-induced activation of adenylate cyclase through the action of G proteins. This receptor binds epinephrine and norepinephrine with approximately equal affinity. Mediates Ras activation through G(s)-alpha- and cAMP-mediated signaling.

go-classifier.description: adenylate cyclase-activating adrenergic receptor signaling pathway
negative regulation of multicellular organism growth
positive regulation of cAMP biosynthetic process
positive regulation of heart rate by epinephrine-norepinephrine
positive regulation of the force of heart contraction by epinephrine-norepinephrine
vasodilation by norepinephrine-epinephrine involved in regulation of systemic arterial blood pressure

article.citation: Kudo S, Uchida M, Odomi M: Metabolism of carteolol by cDNA-expressed human cytochrome P450. Eur J Clin Pharmacol. 1997;52(6):479-85.
Kudo S, Odomi M: Involvement of human cytochrome P450 3A4 in reduced haloperidol oxidation. Eur J Clin Pharmacol. 1998 May;54(3):253-9.

polypeptide.name: Cytochrome P450 2D6
polypeptide.specific-function: Responsible for the metabolism of many drugs and environmental chemicals that it oxidizes. It is involved in the metabolism of drugs such as antiarrhythmics, adrenoceptor antagonists, and tricyclic antidepressants.

go-classifier.description: oxidoreductase activity, acting on paired donors, with incorporation or reduction of molecular oxygen, reduced flavin or flavoprotein as one donor, and incorporation of one atom of oxygen
negative regulation of cellular organofluorine metabolic process
